WRITING.TITLE: Why Saxon is important to me.
WRITING.TEXT:
I discovered Saxon late.
I was 25 before I bought my first Saxon LP. That's nearly ten years past. I'd heard the name before, possibly while flipping through an uncle's record collection, or maybe from watching one of VH1's *super-fuckin-saucy* retrospective mish-moshes. Who knows. I'm more of a casual metal fan, as it represents, maybe, 10-15% of my musical diet? Big on Sabbath and the other '70s heavies, NWOBHM, early thrash and that stoner/sludge/doom/desert business... but that's the extent of it. I never ventured too far in the Byzantine world of so-called extreme metal. Maybe just a pinch, a *sprinkle* of Meshuggah, but, like, whatever.
Anyway, Saxon... fuckin' A. They may look like a "beer soaked pub dart club," and decidedly un-metal, but I'm not one for fashion. But the sound, the *sound,* brothers and sisters, is what pulled me in. They sound like my mind's nostalgic representation of a heavy early '80s metal outfit (I'm only referring to 1979-1984 Saxon, as I can't get into their more recent stuff and don't want to get into their mid-period). After two decades of trying to process all the music that's been part of me, whether it be Maiden/Priest/Lizzy twin-guitar attack or the NES Bionic Commando level where Joe's in the sewer and those blobs come out of the drains and he has to grapple the ceiling with his *Bionic* arm and the music's all like dun-nuh-nuuhhhhh...dun-nuh-nuh-nuhhhhhh ( you know the one), my inner self has printed me a report and it reads "for fuck's sake, put the kids to bed and have a beer or ten and listen to Saxon." And godammit I comply.
As I sit here being figuratively pseudo-pummeled with some of the finest riffs that South Yorkshire ever produced, I can't help but wish that it wasn't my dad who had a big, white trash trailer 'stache and knee-high socks with the blue strip on the calf, but *me*, as I might have had the chance to experience Saxon in real time, as the albums were released. I would have loved to comment on my neighbor's cousin's T-top Trans Am as he peeled out of the Dairy Queen parking lot while simultaneously soaking my girlfriend's basement, all the while slowly nodding my head in agreement to the stylings of "See the Light Shining" or perhaps "Never Surrender." I''ve launched myself into dreamland many-a night thinking of this.
Please forgive me, as English *is* my first language, but can you forgive the face melting guitar of " Street Fighting Gang?" Don't think so, bro.
For your benefit, I beg you to listen to more of this and get back to that early '80s nostalgic haze that calls you, even when you're not entirely sure you were ever there.
My brain's dry now, besos y abrazos.

Oh. All the males on both my parent's sides were Chicago tradesmen; plumbers, electricians, linemen, etc... and I grew up with a "buy it to last" ethic. I also moved to semi-rural Wisconsin seven years ago, where boots and jeans are considered casual wedding attire. I work in an office and wear slacks and wingtips to work, but when I'm off, I'm still very much of a Levi's and Thorogood kinda guy. When I go to "nicer" family functions in a polo and some Sperry's, I still get the occasional "What are you, a fag?" but that may just be my family. Point is, well, I don't have one. :/

I bought mine while managing a restaurant, so I was moving around in them up to twelve, thirteen hours a day and they were great. What they lacked in slip-resistance, they more than made up for in comfort and durability.

I know you said cheap, but the Red Wing Weekender Oxford. Don't be too stingy with the cash when you'll be on your feet that much. The sole will be great for those long hours, they don't look half-bad, and if you treat the leather, it'll resist a lot of those fluids and you can get more than a couple years out of them. You can find a pair of seconds for well under $150 if you do a bit of searching.

For the price, they're not worth it, in my opinion. They are nicely-styled boots, of which I've had two pairs - one harness, one side-zip. The leather tended to crease quite poorly, had too much loose grain, and the stitching was sub-par for the price. If you find a model of theirs that you like, chances are you can find a similar style made by a better manufacturer for a better cost.

WRITING.TITLE: I've reached that sliver of years in my thirties where I dress like the middle-managment type that I am and play music from the '90s with the windows down hoping that someone, anyone goes "That was an amazing song."

WRITING.TEXT:
Oh, Docs, how I miss thee.
I purchased three pairs of 1460s (which were then made in England) in my late teens and early twenties, all of which I beat the hell out of. One pair lasted me two years as a laborer for a plumbing outfit I... labored for. Not bad considering they aren't a true work boot. One pair lasted me five, FIVE, years in the food service industry. That's five years of walking miles and miles a day for fifty to sixty hours a week. Astonishing. The last pair, which were my casual go-to in the beginning of their life, finally gave up the ghost two years back after long ago being relegated to the miscellaneous handy man/painting/I-don't-care-what-happens-to-these spot. They were at least eight years old. Wow.
After Dr. Martens ceased large scale production in England, I have purchased three pairs. The first pair took almost a month to break in, but once they were, they were really comfortable. Until the sole split down the middle after only having them for four months. Hmmm... Well, I chalked it up to a fluke, and order another pair shortly thereafter. This pair was sub-Walmart GARBAGE. The "leather" started cracking after five or six weeks of wear, and...whatever, they were trash. The third pair were plastic-looking leather, and, just... I can't even talk about it. It was the nail in the coffin. I'm done with a company which I once loved; a company that used to make a quality product.
Whenever a candidate for office calls for "bringing back manufacturing," you must realize that those days are gone for good.
Number 36 is killing it.

My grandfather, who was in the Marines in WWII, once told me that the scar on his stomach came from a crazy, bayonet-wielding Japanese soldier. Turns out he had his appendix out. He also told me he was being transported on the *Silver Sides* (which was an actual US submarine in the war) and couldn't handle it, so he "stormed" up to the captain and demanded to be let off, to which the captain replied, "Sure, Tom."
The man could bullshit.

A pair of Old Navy canvas sneakers.
A friend brought them for me seven years ago as a wedding gift (*super* cheap dude, but he's a good guy) because we went "tropical beach" for our honeymoon, and I've beat on them every summer since. They've outlasted two pairs of Sperry's. They couldn't have been more than twenty bucks, but it appears they're indestructible.

I had a pair of ASOS brogues (don't remember the model name) and they came looking quite nice and they were reasonably comfortable from the get-go. After a few weeks, they started creasing horribly, getting loose grain all over and about four months in some of the stitching started to fray, and another month later it failed. I contacted customer service and was put on an endless loop of transfers, carbon copies, and "Uhhhhh..."s. I would not buy from them again.
Shirts would be another story, but this is my experience with the company.

For what it's worth, the MaxWear sole on the Thorogood will most likely last longer and they'll be much more comfortable right out of the box.
